Report Noisy Max and Exponential Mechanism

Posted on 2022-03-06 Edited on 2022-10-17

Let d∈N+d \in \mathbb{N}^+d∈N+ be a positive integer, and u⃗∈Nd\vec{u} \in \mathbb{N}^du∈Nd be a vector.

Definition. Two vectors u⃗,v⃗∈Nd\vec{u}, \vec{v} \in \mathbb{N}^du,v∈Nd are neighboring, denoted as u⃗∼v⃗\vec{u} \sim \vec{v}u∼v, if ∥u⃗−v⃗∥∞=1\Vert \vec{u} - \vec{v} \Vert_\infty = 1∥u−v∥∞​=1.

We are interested in the following research problem.

Problem. Design an ϵ\epsilonϵ-differentially private algorithm to report

arg⁡max⁡i∈[d] ui. \underset{i \in [d]}{\arg\max} \, u_i. i∈[d]argmax​ui​.

Laplacian Mechanism

Since ∥u⃗−v⃗∥∞=1\Vert \vec{u} - \vec{v} \Vert_\infty = 1∥u−v∥∞​=1, it is possible that ∥u⃗−v⃗∥1=d\Vert \vec{u} - \vec{v} \Vert_1 = d∥u−v∥1​=d.
A naive approach would be adding independent Laplacian noise Xi∼Lap(ϵ/d)X_i \sim \mathcal{Lap}( \epsilon / d)Xi​∼Lap(ϵ/d) to each coordinate of u⃗\vec{u}u, and then return

M(u⃗)≐arg⁡max⁡i∈[d](ui+Xi). \mathcal{M}(\vec{u}) \doteq \underset{ i \in [d] }{\arg \max} \big( u_i + X_i \big). M(u)≐i∈[d]argmax​(ui​+Xi​).

Theorem (Privacy Guarantee). The algorithm is ϵ\epsilonϵ-differentially private.

Proof.

This follows directly from Laplacian mechanism.

□\square□

Theorem (Utility Guarantee). With probability at least 1−β1 - \beta1−β, it holds that

uM(u⃗)≥(max⁡i∈[d]ui)−dϵln⁡dβ. u_{ \mathcal{M}(\vec{u}) } \ge \left( \max_{i \in [d] } u_i \right) - \frac{d}{\epsilon} \ln \frac{d}{\beta}. uM(u)​≥(i∈[d]max​ui​)−ϵd​lnβd​.

Proof.
For each i∈[d]i \in [d]i∈[d],

Pr⁡[∣Xi∣≥dϵln⁡dβ]≤βd. \Pr \left[ |X_i| \ge \frac{d}{\epsilon} \ln \frac{d}{\beta} \right] \le \frac{\beta}{d}. Pr[∣Xi​∣≥ϵd​lnβd​]≤dβ​.

Via union bound,

Pr⁡[∃i∈[d]:∣Xi∣≥dϵln⁡dβ]≤β. \Pr \left[ \exists i \in [d] : |X_i| \ge \frac{d}{\epsilon} \ln \frac{d}{\beta} \right] \le \beta. Pr[∃i∈[d]:∣Xi​∣≥ϵd​lnβd​]≤β.

□\square□

Report Noisy Max

Laplacian Noise

It is possible to add Laplacian noise Xi∼Lap(2/ϵ)X_i \sim \mathcal{Lap}(2 / \epsilon)Xi​∼Lap(2/ϵ) to each coordinate of u⃗\vec{u}u, and then return

M(u⃗)≐arg⁡max⁡i∈[d](ui+Xi). \mathcal{M}(\vec{u}) \doteq \underset{ i \in [d] }{\arg \max} \big( u_i + X_i \big). M(u)≐i∈[d]argmax​(ui​+Xi​).

Theorem (Privacy Guarantee). The algorithm is ϵ\epsilonϵ-differentially private.

Proof.
We prove that for each k∈[d]k \in [d]k∈[d], and each u⃗,v⃗∈Nd\vec{u}, \vec{v} \in \mathbb{N}^du,v∈Nd s.t., v⃗∼u⃗\vec{v} \sim \vec{u}v∼u, it holds that

e−ϵ⋅Pr⁡[M(v⃗)=k]≤Pr⁡[M(u⃗)=i]≤eϵ⋅Pr⁡[M(v⃗)=k]. e^{-\epsilon} \cdot \Pr[ \mathcal{M}(\vec{v}) = k] \le \Pr[ \mathcal{M}(\vec{u}) = i ] \le e^\epsilon \cdot \Pr[ \mathcal{M}(\vec{v}) = k]. e−ϵ⋅Pr[M(v)=k]≤Pr[M(u)=i]≤eϵ⋅Pr[M(v)=k].

By symmetry, we prove the claim for just k=nk = nk=n.

For each u⃗∈Nd\vec{u} \in \mathbb{N}^du∈Nd and each sequence s⃗=(s1,…,sn−1)∈Rn−1\vec{s} = (s_1, \ldots, s_{n - 1} ) \in \mathbb{R}^{n - 1}s=(s1​,…,sn−1​)∈Rn−1, define

z(u⃗,s⃗)=max⁡j∈[n−1](uj+sj). z (\vec{u}, \vec s) = \max_{j \in [n - 1] } \big( u_j + s_j \big). z(u,s)=j∈[n−1]max​(uj​+sj​).

Let Xj∼Lap(ϵ/2),j∈[n]X_j \sim \mathcal{Lap}(\epsilon / 2), j \in [n]Xj​∼Lap(ϵ/2),j∈[n], and denote X⃗n−1≐(X1,…,Xn−1)\vec X_{n - 1} \doteq (X_1, \ldots, X_{n - 1})Xn−1​≐(X1​,…,Xn−1​).
The event M(u⃗)=n\mathcal{M}(\vec{u}) = nM(u)=n happens if and only if

z(u⃗,X⃗n−1)<un+Xn. z( \vec{u} , \vec X_{n - 1} ) < u_n + X_n. z(u,Xn−1​)<un​+Xn​.

Fix a sequence s⃗=(s1,…,sn−1)∈Rn−1\vec s = (s_1, \ldots, s_{n - 1} ) \in \mathbb{R}^{n - 1}s=(s1​,…,sn−1​)∈Rn−1:

Pr⁡[M(u⃗)=n∥X⃗n−1=s⃗]=Pr⁡[Xn>z(u⃗,s⃗)−un]={12exp⁡(−ϵ2⋅∣z(u⃗,s⃗)−un∣), if z(u⃗,s⃗)−un>0,1−12exp⁡(−ϵ2⋅∣z(u⃗,s⃗)−un∣), if z(u⃗,s⃗)−un≤0. \begin{aligned} \Pr\big[ \mathcal{M}(\vec{u}) = n \Vert \vec X_{n - 1} = \vec s \big] &= \Pr \big[ X_n > z( \vec{u} , \vec{s} ) - u_n \big] \\ &= \begin{cases} \begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2} \exp \left( -\frac{\epsilon}{2} \cdot | z( \vec{u} , \vec{s} ) - u_n| \right), \end{aligned} &\text{ if } z( \vec{u} , \vec{s} ) - u_n > 0, \\ \begin{aligned} 1 - \frac{1}{2} \exp \left( -\frac{\epsilon}{2} \cdot | z( \vec{u} , \vec{s} ) - u_n| \right), \end{aligned} &\text{ if } z( \vec{u} , \vec{s} ) - u_n \le 0. \end{cases} \end{aligned} Pr[M(u)=n∥Xn−1​=s]​=Pr[Xn​>z(u,s)−un​]=⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​21​exp(−2ϵ​⋅∣z(u,s)−un​∣),​1−21​exp(−2ϵ​⋅∣z(u,s)−un​∣),​​ if z(u,s)−un​>0, if z(u,s)−un​≤0.​​

Similarly,

Pr⁡[M(v⃗)=n∥X⃗n−1=s⃗]=Pr⁡[Xn>z(v⃗,s⃗)−vn]={12exp⁡(−ϵ2⋅∣z(v⃗,s⃗)−vn∣), if z(v⃗,s⃗)−vn>0,1−12exp⁡(−ϵ2⋅∣z(v⃗,s⃗)−vn∣), if z(v⃗,s⃗)−vn≤0. \begin{aligned} \Pr\big[ \mathcal{M}(\vec{v}) = n \Vert \vec X_{n - 1} = \vec s \big] &= \Pr \big[ X_n > z( \vec{v} , \vec{s} ) - v_n \big] \\ &= \begin{cases} \begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2} \exp \left( -\frac{\epsilon}{2} \cdot | z( \vec{v} , \vec{s} ) - v_n | \right), \end{aligned} &\text{ if } z( \vec{v} , \vec{s} ) - v_n > 0, \\ \begin{aligned} 1 - \frac{1}{2} \exp \left( -\frac{\epsilon}{2} \cdot | z( \vec{v} , \vec{s} ) - v_n| \right), \end{aligned} &\text{ if } z( \vec{v} , \vec{s} ) - v_n \le 0. \end{cases} \end{aligned} Pr[M(v)=n∥Xn−1​=s]​=Pr[Xn​>z(v,s)−vn​]=⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​21​exp(−2ϵ​⋅∣z(v,s)−vn​∣),​1−21​exp(−2ϵ​⋅∣z(v,s)−vn​∣),​​ if z(v,s)−vn​>0, if z(v,s)−vn​≤0.​​

Let Δ≐z(u⃗,s⃗)−un−(z(v⃗,s⃗)−vn)\Delta \doteq z( \vec{u} , \vec{s} ) - u_n - (z( \vec{v} , \vec{s} ) - v_n)Δ≐z(u,s)−un​−(z(v,s)−vn​).
The assumption ∥u⃗−v⃗∥∞=1\Vert \vec{u} - \vec{v} \Vert_\infty = 1∥u−v∥∞​=1 implies that ∣Δ∣≤2|\Delta| \le 2∣Δ∣≤2.
WLOG, assume that z(u⃗,s⃗)−un≤z(v⃗,s⃗)−vnz( \vec{u} , \vec{s} ) - u_n \le z( \vec{v} , \vec{s} ) - v_nz(u,s)−un​≤z(v,s)−vn​.
Then

Pr⁡[Xn>z(v⃗,s⃗)−vn]=Pr⁡[Xn+Δ>z(u⃗,s⃗)−un]. \Pr \big[ X_n > z( \vec{v} , \vec{s} ) - v_n \big] = \Pr \big[ X_n + \Delta > z( \vec{u} , \vec{s} ) - u_n \big]. Pr[Xn​>z(v,s)−vn​]=Pr[Xn​+Δ>z(u,s)−un​].

Define Yn≐Xn+ΔY_n \doteq X_n + \DeltaYn​≐Xn​+Δ, which is also a Laplacian random variable with distribution Lap(Δ,2/ϵ)\mathcal{L}ap (\Delta, 2 / \epsilon)Lap(Δ,2/ϵ).
It follows that YnY_nYn​ is (ϵ,0)(\epsilon, 0)(ϵ,0)-close to XnX_nXn​, and

Pr⁡[M(u⃗)=n∥X⃗n−1=s⃗]Pr⁡[M(v⃗)=n∥X⃗n−1=s⃗]=Pr⁡[Xn>z(u⃗,s⃗)−un]Pr⁡[Yn>z(u⃗,s⃗)−un]≤eϵ. \begin{aligned} \frac{ \Pr\big[ \mathcal{M}(\vec{u}) = n \Vert \vec X_{n - 1} = \vec s \big] }{ \Pr \big[ \mathcal{M}(\vec{v}) = n \Vert \vec X_{n - 1} = \vec s \big] } = \frac{ \Pr \big[ X_n > z( \vec{u} , \vec{s} ) - u_n \big] }{ \Pr \big[ Y_n > z( \vec{u} , \vec{s} ) - u_n \big] } \le e^\epsilon. \end{aligned} Pr[M(v)=n∥Xn−1​=s]Pr[M(u)=n∥Xn−1​=s]​=Pr[Yn​>z(u,s)−un​]Pr[Xn​>z(u,s)−un​]​≤eϵ.​

Remark 1. We can also verifies this via the close form expressions.

If 0≤z(u⃗,s⃗)−un0 \le z( \vec{u} , \vec{s} ) - u_n0≤z(u,s)−un​, clearly we have

Pr⁡[M(u⃗)=n∥X⃗n−1=s⃗]Pr⁡[M(v⃗)=n∥X⃗n−1=s⃗]≤exp⁡(ϵ). \begin{aligned} \frac{\Pr\big[ \mathcal{M}(\vec{u}) = n \Vert \vec X_{n - 1} = \vec s \big] }{ \Pr \big[ \mathcal{M}(\vec{v}) = n \Vert \vec X_{n - 1} = \vec s \big] } \le \exp(\epsilon). \end{aligned} Pr[M(v)=n∥Xn−1​=s]Pr[M(u)=n∥Xn−1​=s]​≤exp(ϵ).​

Consider z(v⃗,s⃗)−vn≤0z( \vec{v} , \vec{s} ) - v_n \le 0z(v,s)−vn​≤0.
Let a≐∣z(u⃗,s⃗)−un∣a \doteq |z( \vec{u} , \vec{s} ) - u_n|a≐∣z(u,s)−un​∣, ∣b≐z(v⃗,s⃗)−vn∣|b \doteq z( \vec{v} , \vec{s} ) - v_n|∣b≐z(v,s)−vn​∣, and c=1/2⋅exp⁡(−ϵ/2⋅b)∈[0,1/2]c = 1 / 2 \cdot \exp \left( - {\epsilon} / {2} \cdot b \right) \in [0, 1 / 2]c=1/2⋅exp(−ϵ/2⋅b)∈[0,1/2].
Then a,b≥0a, b \ge 0a,b≥0, a−b≤2a - b \le 2a−b≤2, and

Pr⁡[M(u⃗)=n∥X⃗n−1=s⃗]Pr⁡[M(v⃗)=n∥X⃗n−1=s⃗]=1−12exp⁡(−ϵ2⋅a)1−12exp⁡(−ϵ2⋅b)=1−c⋅exp⁡(−ϵ2⋅(a−b))1−c≤1−c⋅exp⁡(−ϵ)1−c=1eϵeϵ−1+1−c1−c=1eϵ(eϵ−11−c+1)≤1eϵ(eϵ−11−1/2+1)=1eϵ(2eϵ−1)≤exp⁡(ϵ). \begin{aligned} \frac{\Pr\big[ \mathcal{M}(\vec{u}) = n \Vert \vec X_{n - 1} = \vec s \big] }{ \Pr \big[ \mathcal{M}(\vec{v}) = n \Vert \vec X_{n - 1} = \vec s \big] } &= \frac{ 1 - \frac{1}{2} \exp \left( -\frac{\epsilon}{2} \cdot a \right) }{ 1 - \frac{1}{2} \exp \left( -\frac{\epsilon}{2} \cdot b \right) } \\ &= \frac{ 1 - c \cdot \exp \left( -\frac{\epsilon}{2} \cdot (a - b) \right) }{ 1 - c } \\ &\le \frac{ 1 - c \cdot \exp \left( -\epsilon \right) }{ 1 - c } \\ &= \frac{1}{e^\epsilon} \frac{ e^\epsilon - 1 + 1 - c }{ 1 - c } \\ &= \frac{1}{e^\epsilon} \left( \frac{ e^\epsilon - 1 }{ 1 - c } + 1 \right) \\ &\le \frac{1}{e^\epsilon} \left( \frac{ e^\epsilon - 1 }{ 1 - 1 / 2 } + 1 \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{e^\epsilon} \left( 2 e^\epsilon - 1 \right) \\ &\le \exp(\epsilon). \end{aligned} Pr[M(v)=n∥Xn−1​=s]Pr[M(u)=n∥Xn−1​=s]​​=1−21​exp(−2ϵ​⋅b)1−21​exp(−2ϵ​⋅a)​=1−c1−c⋅exp(−2ϵ​⋅(a−b))​≤1−c1−c⋅exp(−ϵ)​=eϵ1​1−ceϵ−1+1−c​=eϵ1​(1−ceϵ−1​+1)≤eϵ1​(1−1/2eϵ−1​+1)=eϵ1​(2eϵ−1)≤exp(ϵ).​

Finally, consider z(u⃗,s⃗)−un<0,z(v⃗,s⃗)−vn>0z( \vec{u} , \vec{s} ) - u_n < 0, z( \vec{v} , \vec{s} ) - v_n > 0z(u,s)−un​<0,z(v,s)−vn​>0.
Let a≐∣z(u⃗,s⃗)−un∣a \doteq |z( \vec{u} , \vec{s} ) - u_n|a≐∣z(u,s)−un​∣, ∣b≐z(v⃗,s⃗)−vn∣|b \doteq z( \vec{v} , \vec{s} ) - v_n|∣b≐z(v,s)−vn​∣, and c=1/2⋅exp⁡(−ϵ/2⋅b)∈[0,1/2]c = 1 / 2 \cdot \exp \left( - {\epsilon} / {2} \cdot b \right) \in [0, 1 / 2]c=1/2⋅exp(−ϵ/2⋅b)∈[0,1/2].
Then a,b≥0a, b \ge 0a,b≥0, a+b≤2a + b \le 2a+b≤2, and

Pr⁡[M(u⃗)=n∥X⃗n−1=s⃗]Pr⁡[M(v⃗)=n∥X⃗n−1=s⃗]=1−12exp⁡(−ϵ2⋅a)12exp⁡(−ϵ2⋅b)=1−c⋅exp⁡(−ϵ2⋅(a−b))c≤1−c⋅exp⁡(−ϵ)c=1c−1eϵ≤2−exp⁡(−ϵ)≤exp⁡(ϵ). \begin{aligned} \frac{\Pr\big[ \mathcal{M}(\vec{u}) = n \Vert \vec X_{n - 1} = \vec s \big] }{ \Pr \big[ \mathcal{M}(\vec{v}) = n \Vert \vec X_{n - 1} = \vec s \big] } &= \frac{ 1 - \frac{1}{2} \exp \left( -\frac{\epsilon}{2} \cdot a \right) }{ \frac{1}{2} \exp \left( -\frac{\epsilon}{2} \cdot b \right) } \\ &= \frac{ 1 - c \cdot \exp \left( -\frac{\epsilon}{2} \cdot (a - b) \right) }{ c } \\ &\le \frac{ 1 - c \cdot \exp \left( -\epsilon \right) }{ c } \\ &= \frac{1}{c} - \frac{ 1 }{ e^\epsilon } \\ &\le 2 - \exp(-\epsilon) \\ &\le \exp(\epsilon). \end{aligned} Pr[M(v)=n∥Xn−1​=s]Pr[M(u)=n∥Xn−1​=s]​​=21​exp(−2ϵ​⋅b)1−21​exp(−2ϵ​⋅a)​=c1−c⋅exp(−2ϵ​⋅(a−b))​≤c1−c⋅exp(−ϵ)​=c1​−eϵ1​≤2−exp(−ϵ)≤exp(ϵ).​

Integrating over X⃗n−1=s⃗\vec X_{n - 1} = \vec sXn−1​=s for all possible s⃗\vec ss finishes the proof.

□\square□

Theorem (Utility Guarantee). With probability at least 1−β1 - \beta1−β, it holds that

uM(u⃗)≥(max⁡i∈[d]ui)−1ϵln⁡dβ. u_{ \mathcal{M}(\vec{u}) } \ge \left( \max_{i \in [d] } u_i \right) - \frac{1}{\epsilon} \ln \frac{d}{\beta}. uM(u)​≥(i∈[d]max​ui​)−ϵ1​lnβd​.

Proof.
For each i∈[d]i \in [d]i∈[d],

Pr⁡[∣Xi∣≥1ϵln⁡dβ]≤βd. \Pr \left[ |X_i| \ge \frac{1}{\epsilon} \ln \frac{d}{\beta} \right] \le \frac{\beta}{d}. Pr[∣Xi​∣≥ϵ1​lnβd​]≤dβ​.

Via union bound,

Pr⁡[∃i∈[d]:∣Xi∣≥1ϵln⁡dβ]≤β. \Pr \left[ \exists i \in [d] : |X_i| \ge \frac{1}{\epsilon} \ln \frac{d}{\beta} \right] \le \beta. Pr[∃i∈[d]:∣Xi​∣≥ϵ1​lnβd​]≤β.

□\square□

Exponential Noise

It is possible to add Exponential noise Xi∼Exp(2/ϵ)X_i \sim \mathcal{Exp}(2 / \epsilon)Xi​∼Exp(2/ϵ) to each coordinate of u⃗\vec{u}u, and then return

M(u⃗)≐arg⁡max⁡i∈[d](ui+Xi). \mathcal{M}(\vec{u}) \doteq \underset{ i \in [d] }{\arg \max} \big( u_i + X_i \big). M(u)≐i∈[d]argmax​(ui​+Xi​).

Following the same vein, we have

Pr⁡[M(u⃗)=n∥X⃗n−1=s⃗]=Pr⁡[Xn>z(u⃗,s⃗)−un]={exp⁡(−ϵ2⋅∣z(u⃗,s⃗)−un∣), if z(u⃗,s⃗)−un>0,1, if z(u⃗,s⃗)−un≤0. \begin{aligned} \Pr\big[ \mathcal{M}(\vec{u}) = n \Vert \vec X_{n - 1} = \vec s \big] &= \Pr \big[ X_n > z( \vec{u} , \vec{s} ) - u_n \big] \\ &= \begin{cases} \begin{aligned} \exp \left( -\frac{\epsilon}{2} \cdot | z( \vec{u} , \vec{s} ) - u_n| \right), \end{aligned} &\text{ if } z( \vec{u} , \vec{s} ) - u_n > 0, \\ \begin{aligned} 1 , \end{aligned} &\text{ if } z( \vec{u} , \vec{s} ) - u_n \le 0. \end{cases} \end{aligned} Pr[M(u)=n∥Xn−1​=s]​=Pr[Xn​>z(u,s)−un​]=⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​exp(−2ϵ​⋅∣z(u,s)−un​∣),​1,​​ if z(u,s)−un​>0, if z(u,s)−un​≤0.​​

And

Pr⁡[M(v⃗)=n∥X⃗n−1=s⃗]=Pr⁡[Xn>z(v⃗,s⃗)−vn]={exp⁡(−ϵ2⋅∣z(v⃗,s⃗)−vn∣), if z(v⃗,s⃗)−vn>0,1, if z(v⃗,s⃗)−vn≤0. \begin{aligned} \Pr\big[ \mathcal{M}(\vec{v}) = n \Vert \vec X_{n - 1} = \vec s \big] &= \Pr \big[ X_n > z( \vec{v} , \vec{s} ) - v_n \big] \\ &= \begin{cases} \begin{aligned} \exp \left( -\frac{\epsilon}{2} \cdot | z( \vec{v} , \vec{s} ) - v_n | \right), \end{aligned} &\text{ if } z( \vec{v} , \vec{s} ) - v_n > 0, \\ \begin{aligned} 1 , \end{aligned} &\text{ if } z( \vec{v} , \vec{s} ) - v_n \le 0. \end{cases} \end{aligned} Pr[M(v)=n∥Xn−1​=s]​=Pr[Xn​>z(v,s)−vn​]=⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​exp(−2ϵ​⋅∣z(v,s)−vn​∣),​1,​​ if z(v,s)−vn​>0, if z(v,s)−vn​≤0.​​

It is straightforward to check that

Pr⁡[M(u⃗)=n∥X⃗n−1=s⃗]Pr⁡[M(v⃗)=n∥X⃗n−1=s⃗]≤exp⁡(ϵ). \begin{aligned} \frac{\Pr\big[ \mathcal{M}(\vec{u}) = n \Vert \vec X_{n - 1} = \vec s \big] }{ \Pr \big[ \mathcal{M}(\vec{v}) = n \Vert \vec X_{n - 1} = \vec s \big] } \le \exp(\epsilon). \end{aligned} Pr[M(v)=n∥Xn−1​=s]Pr[M(u)=n∥Xn−1​=s]​≤exp(ϵ).​

Exponential Mechanism

The exponential mechanism is defined by its output distribution:

Pr⁡[M(u⃗)=i]∝exp⁡(ϵ⋅ui/2),∀i∈[d]. \Pr[\mathcal{M}(\vec{u}) = i] \propto \exp \left( \epsilon \cdot u_i / 2 \right), \quad \forall i \in [d]. Pr[M(u)=i]∝exp(ϵ⋅ui​/2),∀i∈[d].

Normalizing these probabilities give

Pr⁡[M(u⃗)=i]=exp⁡(ϵ⋅ui/2)∑j∈[d]exp⁡(ϵ⋅uj/2),∀i∈[d]. \Pr[\mathcal{M}(\vec{u}) = i] = \frac{ \exp \left( \epsilon \cdot u_i / 2 \right) }{ \sum_{j \in [d] } \exp \left( \epsilon \cdot u_j / 2 \right) }, \quad \forall i \in [d]. Pr[M(u)=i]=∑j∈[d]​exp(ϵ⋅uj​/2)exp(ϵ⋅ui​/2)​,∀i∈[d].

Theorem (Privacy Guarantee). The algorithm is ϵ\epsilonϵ-differentially private.

Proof.
Fix a u⃗∈Nd\vec{u} \in \mathbb{N}^du∈Nd.
We prove that for each i∈[d]i \in [d]i∈[d], and each v⃗∼u⃗\vec{v} \sim \vec{u}v∼u, it holds that

e−ϵ⋅Pr⁡[M(v⃗)=i]≤Pr⁡[M(u⃗)=i]≤eϵ⋅Pr⁡[M(v⃗)=i]. e^{-\epsilon} \cdot \Pr[ \mathcal{M}(\vec{v}) = i] \le \Pr[ \mathcal{M}(\vec{u}) = i ] \le e^\epsilon \cdot \Pr[ \mathcal{M}(\vec{v}) = i]. e−ϵ⋅Pr[M(v)=i]≤Pr[M(u)=i]≤eϵ⋅Pr[M(v)=i].

By symmetry, we prove the claim for just i=ni = ni=n.

Pr⁡[M(u⃗)=n]Pr⁡[M(v⃗)=n]=exp⁡(ϵ⋅un/2)exp⁡(ϵ⋅vn/2)⋅∑j∈[d]exp⁡(ϵ⋅vj/2)∑j∈[d]exp⁡(ϵ⋅uj/2)≤exp⁡(ϵ/2)⋅exp⁡(ϵ/2)=exp⁡(ϵ). \begin{aligned} \frac{\Pr[ \mathcal{M}(\vec{u}) = n] }{\Pr[ \mathcal{M}(\vec{v}) = n] } &= \frac{ \exp \left( \epsilon \cdot u_n / 2 \right) }{ \exp \left( \epsilon \cdot v_n / 2 \right) } \cdot \frac{ \sum_{j \in [d] } \exp \left( \epsilon \cdot v_j / 2 \right) }{ \sum_{j \in [d] } \exp \left( \epsilon \cdot u_j / 2 \right) } \\ &\le \exp( \epsilon / 2 ) \cdot \exp( \epsilon / 2 ) \\ &= \exp( \epsilon ). \end{aligned} Pr[M(v)=n]Pr[M(u)=n]​​=exp(ϵ⋅vn​/2)exp(ϵ⋅un​/2)​⋅∑j∈[d]​exp(ϵ⋅uj​/2)∑j∈[d]​exp(ϵ⋅vj​/2)​≤exp(ϵ/2)⋅exp(ϵ/2)=exp(ϵ).​

The inequality follows since

ui−vi≤∥u⃗−v⃗∥∞≤1,  ⟹  exp⁡(ϵ(ui−vi)/2)≤exp⁡(ϵ/2), ∀i∈[d]. \begin{aligned} u_i - v_i \le \Vert \vec{u} - \vec{v} \Vert_\infty \le 1, \implies \exp( \epsilon (u_i - v_i) / 2) \le \exp( \epsilon / 2), \, \forall i \in [d]. \end{aligned} ui​−vi​≤∥u−v∥∞​≤1,⟹exp(ϵ(ui​−vi​)/2)≤exp(ϵ/2),∀i∈[d].​

□\square□

Theorem (Utility Guarantee). With probability at least 1−β1 - \beta1−β, it holds that

uM(u⃗)≥(max⁡i∈[d]ui)−2ϵ⋅ln⁡∣S∣∣SOPT∣⋅β. u_{ \mathcal{M}(\vec{u}) } \ge \left( \max_{i \in [d] } u_i \right) - \frac{2}{\epsilon} \cdot \ln \frac{|S|}{|S_{OPT}| \cdot \beta}. uM(u)​≥(i∈[d]max​ui​)−ϵ2​⋅ln∣SOPT​∣⋅β∣S∣​.

Proof.
For each t∈Rt \in \mathbb{R}t∈R, the un-normalized probability mass assigned to the set S≐{i∈[d]:ui≤t}S \doteq \{ i \in [d] : u_i \le t \}S≐{i∈[d]:ui​≤t} is at most ∣S∣⋅exp⁡(ϵ⋅t/2)|S| \cdot \exp \left( \epsilon \cdot t / 2\right)∣S∣⋅exp(ϵ⋅t/2).

On the other hand, the un-normalized probability mass assigned to the set SOPT⊆[d]S_{OPT} \subseteq [d]SOPT​⊆[d] consisting of optimal solutions is ∣SOPT∣⋅exp⁡(ϵ⋅(max⁡i∈[d]ui)/2)|S_{OPT}| \cdot \exp \left( \epsilon \cdot \left( \max_{i \in [d] } u_i \right) / 2\right)∣SOPT​∣⋅exp(ϵ⋅(maxi∈[d]​ui​)/2).

Pr⁡[uM(u⃗)≤t]≤∣S∣⋅exp⁡(ϵ⋅t/2)∣SOPT∣⋅exp⁡(ϵ⋅(max⁡i∈[d]ui)/2)≤∣S∣∣SOPT∣exp⁡(ϵ(t−max⁡i∈[d]ui)/2). \begin{aligned} \Pr \left[ u_{ \mathcal{M}(\vec{u}) } \le t \right] &\le \frac{ |S| \cdot \exp \left( \epsilon \cdot t / 2\right) } { |S_{OPT}| \cdot \exp \left( \epsilon \cdot \left( \max_{i \in [d] } u_i \right) / 2 \right) } \\ &\le \frac{|S|}{|S_{OPT}|} \exp \left( \epsilon \left( t - \max_{i \in [d] } u_i \right) / 2 \right). \end{aligned} Pr[uM(u)​≤t]​≤∣SOPT​∣⋅exp(ϵ⋅(maxi∈[d]​ui​)/2)∣S∣⋅exp(ϵ⋅t/2)​≤∣SOPT​∣∣S∣​exp(ϵ(t−i∈[d]max​ui​)/2).​

To bound the last term by β\betaβ, we can set

t=(max⁡i∈[d]ui)−2ϵ⋅ln⁡∣S∣∣SOPT∣⋅β. t = \left( \max_{i \in [d] } u_i \right) - \frac{2}{\epsilon} \cdot \ln \frac{|S|}{|S_{OPT}| \cdot \beta}. t=(i∈[d]max​ui​)−ϵ2​⋅ln∣SOPT​∣⋅β∣S∣​.

□\square□

Gumbel Noise

A random variable XXX follows the Gumbel distribution Gumbel(μ,b)\mathcal{Gumbel}(\mu, b)Gumbel(μ,b) if its density is given by

p(x)≐1b⋅exp⁡(−(x−μ)/b−e−(x−μ)/b)=1b⋅e−(x−μ)/b⋅exp⁡(−e−(x−μ)/b),∀x∈R. p(x) \doteq \frac{1}{b} \cdot \exp \left( - (x - \mu) / b - e^{- (x - \mu) / b} \right) = \frac{1}{b} \cdot e^{ - (x - \mu) / b } \cdot \exp \left(- e^{- (x - \mu) / b} \right), \forall x \in \mathbb{R}. p(x)≐b1​⋅exp(−(x−μ)/b−e−(x−μ)/b)=b1​⋅e−(x−μ)/b⋅exp(−e−(x−μ)/b),∀x∈R.

It follows that the cumulative distribution of XXX is

Pr⁡[X≤t]=∫−∞t1b⋅e−(x−μ)/b⋅exp⁡(−e−(x−μ)/b) dx=−∫−∞texp⁡(−e−(x−μ)/b) de−(x−μ)/b=∫exp⁡(−(t−μ)/b)∞exp⁡(−y) dy=exp⁡(−e−(t−μ)/b). \begin{aligned} \Pr[ X \le t ] &= \int_{-\infty}^t \frac{1}{b} \cdot e^{ - (x - \mu) / b } \cdot \exp \left(- e^{- (x - \mu) / b} \right) \, d x \\ &= - \int_{-\infty}^t \exp \left(- e^{- (x - \mu) / b} \right) \, d e^{ - (x - \mu) / b } \\ &= \int^{\infty}_{\exp(- (t - \mu) / b)} \exp \left(- y \right) \, d y \\ &= \exp \left(- e^{ - (t - \mu) / b } \right). \end{aligned} Pr[X≤t]​=∫−∞t​b1​⋅e−(x−μ)/b⋅exp(−e−(x−μ)/b)dx=−∫−∞t​exp(−e−(x−μ)/b)de−(x−μ)/b=∫exp(−(t−μ)/b)∞​exp(−y)dy=exp(−e−(t−μ)/b).​

Theorem. If we add Gumbel noise Xi∼Gumbel(0,2/ϵ)X_i \sim \mathcal{Gumbel}(0, 2 / \epsilon)Xi​∼Gumbel(0,2/ϵ) to each coordinate of u⃗\vec{u}u, and then return

M(u⃗)≐arg⁡max⁡i∈[d](ui+Xi), \mathcal{M}(\vec{u}) \doteq \underset{ i \in [d] }{\arg \max} \big( u_i + X_i \big), M(u)≐i∈[d]argmax​(ui​+Xi​),

the output has the same distribution as the one of exponential mechanism.

Proof.
Let b=2/ϵb = 2 / \epsilonb=2/ϵ, and Zi≐ui+XiZ_i \doteq u_i + X_iZi​≐ui​+Xi​.
Then Zi∼Gumbel(ui,b)Z_i \sim \mathcal{Gumbel}(u_i, b)Zi​∼Gumbel(ui​,b), and

Pr⁡[M(u⃗)=n]=∫−∞∞(p(zn)⋅∏i∈[n−1]Pr⁡[Zi≤zn]) dzn=∫−∞∞(1b⋅e−(zn−un)/b⋅exp⁡(−e−(zn−un)/b)⋅∏i∈[n−1]exp⁡(−e−(zn−ui)/b)) dzn=eun/b⋅∫−∞∞(1b⋅e−zn/b⋅exp⁡(−e−zn/b⋅∑i∈[n]eui/b)) dzn=−eun/b⋅∫∞0exp⁡(−y⋅∑i∈[n]eui/b) dy(y≐e−zn/b)=exp⁡(un/b)∑i∈[n]exp⁡(ui/b). \begin{aligned} \Pr[ \mathcal{M}(\vec{u}) = n] &= \int_{-\infty}^\infty \left( p(z_n) \cdot \prod_{i \in [n - 1]} \Pr[ Z_i \le z_n ] \right) \, d z_n \\ &= \int_{-\infty}^\infty \left( \frac{1}{b} \cdot e^{ - (z_n - u_n) / b } \cdot \exp \left(- e^{- (z_n - u_n) / b} \right) \cdot \prod_{i \in [n - 1]} \exp \left(- e^{- (z_n - u_i) / b } \right) \right) \, d z_n \\ &= e^{ u_n / b } \cdot \int_{-\infty}^\infty \left( \frac{1}{b} \cdot e^{ - z_n / b } \cdot \exp \left(- e^{- z_n / b} \cdot \sum_{i \in [n ]} e^{ u_i / b } \right) \right) \, d z_n \\ &= - e^{ u_n / b } \cdot \int_{\infty}^0 \exp \left( - y \cdot \sum_{i \in [n ]} e^{ u_i / b } \right) \, d y & (y \doteq e^{-z_n/b} ) \\ &= \frac{ \exp \left( u_n / b \right) }{ \sum_{i \in [n]} \exp \left( u_i / b \right) }. \end{aligned} Pr[M(u)=n]​=∫−∞∞​⎝⎛​p(zn​)⋅i∈[n−1]∏​Pr[Zi​≤zn​]⎠⎞​dzn​=∫−∞∞​⎝⎛​b1​⋅e−(zn​−un​)/b⋅exp(−e−(zn​−un​)/b)⋅i∈[n−1]∏​exp(−e−(zn​−ui​)/b)⎠⎞​dzn​=eun​/b⋅∫−∞∞​⎝⎛​b1​⋅e−zn​/b⋅exp⎝⎛​−e−zn​/b⋅i∈[n]∑​eui​/b⎠⎞​⎠⎞​dzn​=−eun​/b⋅∫∞0​exp⎝⎛​−y⋅i∈[n]∑​eui​/b⎠⎞​dy=∑i∈[n]​exp(ui​/b)exp(un​/b)​.​(y≐e−zn​/b)​

□\square□

Approximate Densest Subgraph

Posted on 2022-02-11 Edited on 2022-02-12

Let G=(V,E)G = (V, E)G=(V,E) be an undirected graph with ∣V∣=n|V| = n∣V∣=n vertices and ∣E∣=m|E| = m∣E∣=m edges.
For each S⊂VS \subset VS⊂V, denote E(S)E(S)E(S) the set of edges in the subgraph induced by SSS, i.e.,

E(S)≐{(u,v)∈E:u,v∈S}. E(S) \doteq \{ (u, v) \in E : u, v \in S \}. E(S)≐{(u,v)∈E:u,v∈S}.

The density of the subgraph induced by SSS is

dG(S)≐∣E(S)∣∣S∣. d_G(S) \doteq \frac{|E(S)|}{|S|}. dG​(S)≐∣S∣∣E(S)∣​.

Problem. Find S∗⊂VS^* \subset VS∗⊂V, s.t. dG(S∗)d_G(S^*)dG​(S∗) is maximized.

Greedy Algorithm

Definition. Given S⊂VS \subset VS⊂V, for each u∈Su \in Su∈S, define the set of edges incident to uuu in SSS as

E(u,S)≐{(u,v)∈E(S)}. E(u, S) \doteq \{ (u, v) \in E(S) \}. E(u,S)≐{(u,v)∈E(S)}.

Definition. A function w:E→Vw: E \rightarrow Vw:E→V is called an edge assignment, if it maps each edge (u,v)∈E(u, v) \in E(u,v)∈E to one of its endpoints {u,v}\{u, v \}{u,v}.

There is a linear time, 2-approximation greedy algorithm [1] which works as follows.

Greedy Algorithm.

  1. S1←VS_1 \leftarrow VS1​←V;
  2. for i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n] do
  3. \qquad ui←arg⁡min⁡u∈Si∣E(u,Si)∣u_i \leftarrow \arg\min_{u \in S_i} |E(u, S_i)|ui​←argminu∈Si​​∣E(u,Si​)∣;
  4. \qquad Si+1←Si∖{ui}S_{i + 1} \leftarrow S_i \setminus \{ u_i \}Si+1​←Si​∖{ui​};
  5. \qquad for e=(ui,v)∈E(ui,Si)e = (u_i, v) \in E(u_i, S_i)e=(ui​,v)∈E(ui​,Si​) do
  6. \qquad \qquad w(e)←uiw(e) \leftarrow u_iw(e)←ui​;
  7. k←arg⁡max⁡i∈n]∣E(ui,Si)∣k \leftarrow \arg\max_{i \in n]} |E(u_i, S_i)|k←argmaxi∈n]​∣E(ui​,Si​)∣;
  8. return SkS_kSk​;

Approximation Guarantee

Definition. Given an edge assignment www, for each u∈Vu \in Vu∈V, denote the set of edges assigned to uuu as

Aw(u)≐{e=(u,v)∈E:w(e)=u}. A_w(u) \doteq \{ e = (u, v) \in E : w(e) = u \}. Aw​(u)≐{e=(u,v)∈E:w(e)=u}.

The approximation guarantee relies on the following lemma.

Lemma. For edge assignment www and each S⊂VS \subset VS⊂V, it holds that

max⁡u∈V∣Aw(u)∣≥dG(S). \max_{u \in V} |A_w(u)| \ge d_G(S). u∈Vmax​∣Aw​(u)∣≥dG​(S).

Proof.
Observe that all edges in E(S)E(S)E(S) are assigned to vertices in SSS.
It follows that

max⁡u∈V∣Aw(u)∣≥max⁡u∈S∣Aw(u)∣≥∣E(S)∣∣S∣=dG(S). \max_{u \in V} |A_w(u)| \ge \max_{u \in S} |A_w(u)| \ge \frac{|E(S)|}{|S|} = d_G(S). u∈Vmax​∣Aw​(u)∣≥u∈Smax​∣Aw​(u)∣≥∣S∣∣E(S)∣​=dG​(S).

□\square□

Theorem. The solution SkS_kSk​ satisfies

dG(Sk)≥12⋅dG(S∗). d_G(S_k) \ge \frac{1}{2} \cdot d_G (S^*). dG​(Sk​)≥21​⋅dG​(S∗).

Proof.
Let www be the assignment constructed by the greedy algorithm, and denote

dmax⁡≐max⁡u∈V∣Aw(u)∣=max⁡i∈[n]∣E(ui,Si)∣=∣E(uk,Sk)∣. d_{\max} \doteq \max_{u \in V} |A_w(u)| = \max_{i \in [n]} |E(u_i, S_i)| = |E(u_k, S_k)|. dmax​≐u∈Vmax​∣Aw​(u)∣=i∈[n]max​∣E(ui​,Si​)∣=∣E(uk​,Sk​)∣.

Via the previous lemma, it holds that

dG(S∗)≤dmax⁡=∣E(uk,Sk)∣. d_G(S^*) \le d_{\max} = |E(u_k, S_k)|. dG​(S∗)≤dmax​=∣E(uk​,Sk​)∣.

Further, as uku_kuk​ is the vertices with minimum degree in the subgraph induced by SkS_kSk​, ∣E(uk,Sk)∣|E(u_k, S_k)|∣E(uk​,Sk​)∣ should be upper bounded by the average degree in SkS_kSk​:

dG(S∗)≤∣E(uk,Sk)∣≤2⋅∣E(Sk)∣∣Sk∣=2⋅dG(Sk). d_G(S^*) \le |E(u_k, S_k)| \le 2 \cdot \frac{|E(S_k)|}{ |S_k| } = 2 \cdot d_G(S_k). dG​(S∗)≤∣E(uk​,Sk​)∣≤2⋅∣Sk​∣∣E(Sk​)∣​=2⋅dG​(Sk​).

□\square□

Running Time

Theorem. The algorithm can be implemented in O(m+n)O(m + n)O(m+n) time.

Proof.

We can maintain the degrees of the vertices in Si,i∈[n]S_i, i \in [n]Si​,i∈[n] dynamically.

  1. At the beginning of the algorithm, set d(u)=∣E(u,V)∣=∣E(u,Si)∣d(u) = |E(u, V)| = |E(u, S_i)|d(u)=∣E(u,V)∣=∣E(u,Si​)∣ for each u∈Vu \in Vu∈V.
    We maintain the invariant that d(u)=∣E(u,Si)∣d(u) = |E(u, S_i)|d(u)=∣E(u,Si​)∣ at the beginning of each iteration i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n].

  2. At the i(th)i^{(th)}i(th) iteration, when uiu_iui​ is removed from SiS_iSi​ to construct Si+1S_{i + 1}Si+1​, we decrease d(v)d(v)d(v) by 111, if (ui,v)∈E(Si)(u_i, v) \in E(S_i)(ui​,v)∈E(Si​).

It is easy to see that the invariant is maintained, and the total update time is O(m)O(m)O(m).

Next, we design a data structure that supports the extraction of uiu_iui​, the vertex with minimum degree in SiS_iSi​, in O(1)O(1)O(1) time.
We keep an array with size nnn.

  • Each vertex uuu is kept in the d(u)d(u)d(u)-th bucket of the array.
    When d(u)d(u)d(u) is updated, we update the bucket of uuu correspondingly.
    The total update cost is O(m)O(m)O(m).

  • At the beginning of the algorithm, we search bucket 0,1,…0, 1, \ldots0,1,… , until we find the first non-empty bucket j∈[n]j \in [n]j∈[n]. Then we extract a vertex uuu from the bucket jjj, and updates the d(v)d(v)d(v) for which vvv is neighbor of uuu in the induced subgraph. The update decreases d(v)d(v)d(v) by 111. Therefore, the bucket max⁡{0,j−1}\max \{ 0, j - 1 \}max{0,j−1} can become non-empty at the next iteration, from which we should try to find the next vertex with minimum degree. There are nnn iteration, and we can move backward at the array by at most nnn steps. It follows that the total searching cost in the array is O(n)O(n)O(n).

□\square□

Reference

[1] M. Charikar, “Greedy Approximation Algorithms for Finding Dense Components in a Graph,” 2000.

Sparse Vector

Posted on 2022-02-08 Edited on 2024-04-11

Let (X,∥⋅∥)(\mathcal{X}, \Vert \cdot \Vert)(X,∥⋅∥) be metric space.

Definition. Two elements D,D′∈XD, D' \in \mathcal{X}D,D′∈X are neighboring, denoted as D∼D′D \sim D'D∼D′, if ∥D′,D′∥=1\Vert D', D' \Vert = 1∥D′,D′∥=1.
Definition. A function q:X→Rq: \mathcal{X} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}q:X→R has sensitivity Δ∈R+\Delta \in \mathbb{R}^+Δ∈R+, if

Δ=sup⁡D,D′∈X,D∼D′∣q(D)−q(D′)∣. \Delta = \sup_{ D, D' \in \mathcal{X}, D \sim D' } | q(D) - q(D') |. Δ=D,D′∈X,D∼D′sup​∣q(D)−q(D′)∣.

Problem

Let qi:X→R,i∈N+q_i: \mathcal{X} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}, i \in \mathbb{N}^+qi​:X→R,i∈N+ be a sequence of functions with sensitivity Δ\DeltaΔ.
Let t∈Rt \in \mathbb{R}t∈R be a threshold.
Design an ϵ\epsilonϵ-differentially private algorithm, that reports the first i∈N+i \in \mathbb{N}^+i∈N+ for which qi(D)q_i(D)qi​(D) is near or above ttt.

Mechanism One

Definition. For each b∈R+b \in \mathbb{R}^+b∈R+, let Lap(b)\mathcal{Lap}(b)Lap(b) be the Laplacian distribution with parameter bbb.

The algorithm is described as follows.

Algorithm A\mathcal{A}A.

  1. t^←t+Z\hat t \leftarrow t + Zt^←t+Z where Z∼Lap(3Δ/ϵ)Z \sim \mathcal{Lap}(3 \Delta / \epsilon)Z∼Lap(3Δ/ϵ)
  2. for i∈N+i \in \mathbb{N}^+i∈N+ do
  3. \qquad q^i(D)←qi(D)+Xi\hat q_i(D) \leftarrow q_i(D) + X_iq^​i​(D)←qi​(D)+Xi​, where Xi∼Lap(3Δ/ϵ)X_i \sim \mathcal{Lap}( 3 \Delta / \epsilon)Xi​∼Lap(3Δ/ϵ)
  4. \qquad if q^i(D)≥t^\hat q_i(D) \ge \hat tq^​i​(D)≥t^ then
  5. \qquad\qquad output ⊥\bot⊥
  6. \qquad\qquad halt
  7. \qquad else
  8. \qquad\qquad output ⊤\top⊤

Note that it is necessary to add noise to ttt, to obtain t^\hat{t}t^.

Otherwise, assume that A(D)=A(D′)=⊤…⊤⏟n occurrences⊥\mathcal{A} (D) = \mathcal{A} (D') = \underbrace{\top \ldots \top}_{ n \text{ occurrences} } \botA(D)=A(D′)=n occurrences⊤…⊤​​⊥ for some n∈Nn \in \mathbb{N}n∈N and neighboring datasets DDD and D′D'D′.

Assume further that t=0t = 0t=0, qi(D)=Δq_i(D) = \Deltaqi​(D)=Δ and qi(D′)=0q_i(D') = 0qi​(D′)=0 for all i∈Ni \in \mathbb{N}i∈N.
Then

\begin{align*} \Pr[ \mathcal{A} (D) = \underbrace{\top \ldots \top}_{ n \text{ occurrences} } \bot ] &= \left( \frac{1}{2} \right)^{n + 1} \exp \left( - \frac{\epsilon \cdot n }{3} \right) \left( 1 - \exp \left( - \frac{\epsilon}{3} \right)\right). \\ \Pr[ \mathcal{A} (D') = \underbrace{\top \ldots \top}_{ n \text{ occurrences} } \bot ] &= \left( \frac{1}{2} \right)^{n + 1}. \end{align*}

Privacy Guarantee

Let D′D'D′ be a neighboring dataset of DDD.

Theorem. For each i∈N+i \in \mathbb{N}^+i∈N+, let si≐⊤…⊤⏟i−1 occurrences⊥s_i \doteq \underbrace{\top \ldots \top}_{ i - 1 \text{ occurrences} } \botsi​≐i−1 occurrences⊤…⊤​​⊥.
Then

e−ϵ≤Pr⁡[A(D)=si]Pr⁡[A(D′)=si]≤eϵ. e^{-\epsilon} \le \frac{\Pr[ \mathcal{A}(D) = s_i ]}{\Pr[ \mathcal{A}(D') = s_i ]} \le e^{\epsilon}. e−ϵ≤Pr[A(D′)=si​]Pr[A(D)=si​]​≤eϵ.

Proof 1.

Fix an i∈N+i \in \mathbb{N}^+i∈N+.
For each dataset DDD and each x⃗i−1=(x1,…,xi−1)∈Ri−1\vec x_{i - 1} = (x_1, \ldots, x_{i - 1} ) \in \mathbb{R}^{i - 1}xi−1​=(x1​,…,xi−1​)∈Ri−1, define

M(D,x⃗i−1)=max⁡j∈[i−1](qj(D)+xj). M(D, \vec x_{i - 1}) = \max_{j \in [i - 1]} \Big( q_j(D) + x_j \Big). M(D,xi−1​)=j∈[i−1]max​(qj​(D)+xj​).

Denote X⃗i−1≐(X1,…,Xi−1)\vec X_{i - 1} \doteq (X_1, \ldots, X_{i - 1})Xi−1​≐(X1​,…,Xi−1​), and
the event A(D)=si\mathcal{A}(D) = s_iA(D)=si​ happens if and only if

M(D,X⃗i−1)<t^≤q^i(D). M(D, \vec X_{i - 1}) < \hat t \le \hat q_i(D). M(D,Xi−1​)<t^≤q^​i​(D).

Fix a sequence x⃗i−1=(x1,…,xi−1)∈Ri−1\vec x_{i - 1} = (x_1, \ldots, x_{i - 1} ) \in \mathbb{R}^{i - 1}xi−1​=(x1​,…,xi−1​)∈Ri−1.
Let μ\muμ be a shorthand of Lap(3Δ/ϵ)\mathcal{Lap}(3 \Delta / \epsilon)Lap(3Δ/ϵ), and FFF be its cumulative function.
Since the random variables Z,X⃗i−1,XiZ, \vec X_{i - 1}, X_iZ,Xi−1​,Xi​ are independent, via Fubini’s theorem,

Pr⁡[A(D)=si∥X⃗i−1=x⃗i−1]=Pr⁡[M(D,x⃗i−1)<t^≤q^i(D)]=Pr⁡[M(D,x⃗i−1)<t+Z≤qi(D)+Xi]=Ez∼μ[I[M(D,x⃗i−1)<t+z]⋅(1−F(t+z−qi(D)))]=Ez∼μ[I[M(D,x⃗i−1)<t+z]⋅F(−t−z+qi(D))]=∫M(D,x⃗i−1)−t∞p(z)⋅F(−t−z+qi(D)) dz=∫M(D′,x⃗i−1)−t∞p(z+κ)⋅F(−t−z−κ+qi(D)) dz, \begin{aligned} \Pr \big[ \mathcal{A}(D) = s_i \Vert \vec X_{i - 1} = \vec x_{i - 1} \big] &= \Pr \big[ M(D, \vec x_{i - 1}) < \hat t \le \hat q_i(D) \big] \\ &= \Pr \big[ M(D, \vec x_{i - 1}) < t + Z \le q_i(D) + X_i \big] \\ &= \mathbb{E}_{z \sim \mu} \left[ \mathbb{I} \Big[ M(D, \vec x_{i - 1}) < t + z \Big] \cdot \big( 1 - F ( t + z - q_i(D) ) \big) \right] \\ &= \mathbb{E}_{z \sim \mu} \left[ \mathbb{I} \Big[ M(D, \vec x_{i - 1}) < t + z \Big] \cdot F \big( - t - z + q_i(D) \big) \right] \\ &= \int_{M(D, \vec x_{i - 1}) - t}^\infty p(z) \cdot F \big( - t - z + q_i(D) \big) \, d z \\ &= \int_{M(D', \vec x_{i - 1}) - t}^\infty p\big( z + \kappa \big) \cdot F \big( - t - z - \kappa + q_i(D) \big) \, d z, \end{aligned} Pr[A(D)=si​∥Xi−1​=xi−1​]​=Pr[M(D,xi−1​)<t^≤q^​i​(D)]=Pr[M(D,xi−1​)<t+Z≤qi​(D)+Xi​]=Ez∼μ​[I[M(D,xi−1​)<t+z]⋅(1−F(t+z−qi​(D)))]=Ez∼μ​[I[M(D,xi−1​)<t+z]⋅F(−t−z+qi​(D))]=∫M(D,xi−1​)−t∞​p(z)⋅F(−t−z+qi​(D))dz=∫M(D′,xi−1​)−t∞​p(z+κ)⋅F(−t−z−κ+qi​(D))dz,​

where κ≐M(D,x⃗i−1)−M(D′,x⃗i−1)\kappa \doteq M(D, \vec x_{i - 1}) - M(D', \vec x_{i - 1})κ≐M(D,xi−1​)−M(D′,xi−1​).

Similarly, the conditional probability density of Pr⁡[A(D′)=si]\Pr\big[ \mathcal{A}(D') = s_i \big]Pr[A(D′)=si​] is given by

Pr⁡[A(D′)=si∥X⃗i−1=x⃗i−1]=∫M(D′,x⃗i−1)−t∞p(z)⋅F(−t−z+qi(D′)) dz. \begin{aligned} \Pr \big[ \mathcal{A}(D') = s_i \Vert \vec X_{i - 1} = \vec x_{i - 1} \big] &= \int_{M(D', \vec x_{i - 1}) - t}^\infty p(z) \cdot F \big( - t - z + q_i(D') \big) \, d z. \end{aligned} Pr[A(D′)=si​∥Xi−1​=xi−1​]​=∫M(D′,xi−1​)−t∞​p(z)⋅F(−t−z+qi​(D′))dz.​

Comparing p(z)p(z)p(z) and p(z+κ)p(z + \kappa)p(z+κ), F(−t−z−κ+qi(D))F \big( - t - z - \kappa + q_i(D) \big)F(−t−z−κ+qi​(D)) and F(−t−z+qi(D′))F \big( - t - z + q_i(D') \big)F(−t−z+qi​(D′)) finishes the proof.

□\square□

Proof 2.

Fix an i∈N+i \in \mathbb{N}^+i∈N+.
For each dataset DDD and each x⃗i−1=(x1,…,xi−1)∈Ri−1\vec x_{i - 1} = (x_1, \ldots, x_{i - 1} ) \in \mathbb{R}^{i - 1}xi−1​=(x1​,…,xi−1​)∈Ri−1, define

M(D,x⃗i−1)=max⁡j∈[i−1](qj(D)+xj). M(D, \vec x_{i - 1}) = \max_{j \in [i - 1]} \Big( q_j(D) + x_j \Big). M(D,xi−1​)=j∈[i−1]max​(qj​(D)+xj​).

Denote X⃗i−1≐(X1,…,Xi−1)\vec X_{i - 1} \doteq (X_1, \ldots, X_{i - 1})Xi−1​≐(X1​,…,Xi−1​), and
the event A(D)=si\mathcal{A}(D) = s_iA(D)=si​ happens if and only if

Fix a sequence x⃗i−1=(x1,…,xi−1)∈Ri−1\vec x_{i - 1} = (x_1, \ldots, x_{i - 1} ) \in \mathbb{R}^{i - 1}xi−1​=(x1​,…,xi−1​)∈Ri−1.
Since the random variables Z,X⃗i−1,XiZ, \vec X_{i - 1}, X_iZ,Xi−1​,Xi​ are independent,

Pr⁡[A(D)=si∥X⃗i−1=x⃗i−1]=Pr⁡[M(D,x⃗i−1)<t^≤q^i(D)]=Pr⁡[M(D,x⃗i−1)<t+Z≤qi(D)+Xi]=∫∫p(z)⋅p(xi)⋅I[M(D,x⃗i−1)<t+z≤qi(D)+xi] dxi dz, \begin{aligned} \Pr \big[ \mathcal{A}(D) = s_i \Vert \vec X_{i - 1} = \vec x_{i - 1} \big] &= \Pr \big[ M(D, \vec x_{i - 1}) < \hat t \le \hat q_i(D) \big] \\ &= \Pr \big[ M(D, \vec x_{i - 1}) < t + Z \le q_i(D) + X_i \big] \\ &= \int \int p(z) \cdot p(x_i) \cdot \mathbb{I} \Big[ M(D, \vec x_{i - 1}) < t + z \le q_i(D) + x_i \Big] \, d x_i \, dz, \end{aligned} Pr[A(D)=si​∥Xi−1​=xi−1​]​=Pr[M(D,xi−1​)<t^≤q^​i​(D)]=Pr[M(D,xi−1​)<t+Z≤qi​(D)+Xi​]=∫∫p(z)⋅p(xi​)⋅I[M(D,xi−1​)<t+z≤qi​(D)+xi​]dxi​dz,​

where p(z)p(z)p(z) and p(xi)p(x_i)p(xi​) are probability densities of ZZZ and XiX_iXi​, respectively.
Similarly, the conditional probability density of Pr⁡[A(D′)=si]\Pr\big[ \mathcal{A}(D') = s_i \big]Pr[A(D′)=si​] is given by

Pr⁡[A(D′)=si∥X⃗i−1=x⃗i−1]=Pr⁡[M(D′,x⃗i−1)<t^≤q^i(D′)]=Pr⁡[M(D′,x⃗i−1)<t+Z≤qi(D′)+Xi]=∫∫p(z′)⋅p(xi′)⋅I[M(D′,x⃗i−1)<t+z′≤qi(D′)+xi′] dxi′ dz′. \begin{aligned} \Pr \big[ \mathcal{A}(D') = s_i \Vert \vec X_{i - 1} = \vec x_{i - 1} \big] &= \Pr \big[ M(D', \vec x_{i - 1}) < \hat t \le \hat q_i(D') \big] \\ &= \Pr \big[ M(D', \vec x_{i - 1}) < t + Z \le q_i(D') + X_i \big] \\ &= \int \int p(z') \cdot p(x_i') \cdot \mathbb{I} \Big[ M(D', \vec x_{i - 1}) < t + z' \le q_i(D') + x_i' \Big] \, d x_i' \, dz'. \end{aligned} Pr[A(D′)=si​∥Xi−1​=xi−1​]​=Pr[M(D′,xi−1​)<t^≤q^​i​(D′)]=Pr[M(D′,xi−1​)<t+Z≤qi​(D′)+Xi​]=∫∫p(z′)⋅p(xi′​)⋅I[M(D′,xi−1​)<t+z′≤qi​(D′)+xi′​]dxi′​dz′.​

Suppose that the following equations holds:

t+z′−M(D′,x⃗i−1)=t+z−M(D,x⃗i−1),qi(D′)+xi′−(t+z′)=qi(D)+xi−(t+z). \begin{aligned} t + z' - M(D', \vec x_{i - 1}) &= t + z - M(D, \vec x_{i - 1}), \\ q_i(D') + x_i' - (t + z') &= q_i(D) + x_i - (t + z). \end{aligned} t+z′−M(D′,xi−1​)qi​(D′)+xi′​−(t+z′)​=t+z−M(D,xi−1​),=qi​(D)+xi​−(t+z).​

Then

I[M(D′,x⃗i−1)<t+z′≤qi(D′)+xi′]=I[M(D,x⃗i−1)<t+z≤qi(D)+xi]. \mathbb{I} \Big[ M(D', \vec x_{i - 1}) < t + z' \le q_i(D') + x_i' \Big] = \mathbb{I} \Big[ M(D, \vec x_{i - 1}) < t + z \le q_i(D) + x_i \Big]. I[M(D′,xi−1​)<t+z′≤qi​(D′)+xi′​]=I[M(D,xi−1​)<t+z≤qi​(D)+xi​].

But this implies that

∣z′−z∣=∣M(D′,x⃗i−1)−M(D,x⃗i−1)∣≤Δ∣xi′−xi∣=∣z′−qi(D′)−z+qi(D)∣=∣M(D′,x⃗i−1)−M(D,x⃗i−1)+qi(D)−qi(D′)∣≤2⋅Δ. \begin{aligned} |z' - z| &= |M(D', \vec x_{i - 1}) - M(D, \vec x_{i - 1})| \le \Delta \\ |x_i' - x_i| &= |z' - q_i(D') - z + q_i(D)| \\ &= |M(D', \vec x_{i - 1}) - M(D, \vec x_{i - 1}) + q_i(D) - q_i(D')| \\ &\le 2 \cdot \Delta. \end{aligned} ∣z′−z∣∣xi′​−xi​∣​=∣M(D′,xi−1​)−M(D,xi−1​)∣≤Δ=∣z′−qi​(D′)−z+qi​(D)∣=∣M(D′,xi−1​)−M(D,xi−1​)+qi​(D)−qi​(D′)∣≤2⋅Δ.​

Further, observe that

∣dxi′dxi,dxi′dzdz′dxi,dz′dz∣=∣1,00,1∣=1, \begin{vmatrix} \begin{aligned} \frac{d x_i'}{d_{x_i}}, &\frac{d x_i'}{d_z} \\ \frac{d z'}{d_{x_i}}, &\frac{d z'}{d_z} \end{aligned} \end{vmatrix} = \begin{vmatrix} 1, &0 \\ 0, &1 \end{vmatrix} = 1, ∣∣∣∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​dxi​​dxi′​​,dxi​​dz′​,​dz​dxi′​​dz​dz′​​​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​=∣∣∣∣∣​1,0,​01​∣∣∣∣∣​=1,

Therefore, by integration by substitution,

Pr⁡[A(D)=si∥X⃗i−1=x⃗i−1]Pr⁡[A(D′)=si∥X⃗i−1=x⃗i−1]=∫∫p(z)⋅p(xi)⋅I[M(D,x⃗i−1)<t+z≤qi(D)+xi] dxi dz∫∫p(z′)⋅p(xi′)⋅I[M(D′,x⃗i−1)<t+z′≤qi(D′)+xi′] dxi′ dz′=∫∫p(z)⋅p(xi)⋅I[M(D,x⃗i−1)<t+z≤qi(D)+xi] dxi dz∫∫p(z′)⋅p(xi′)⋅I[M(D,x⃗i−1)<t+z≤qi(D)+xi] dxi dz≤exp⁡(Δ⋅ϵ3Δ)⋅exp⁡(2⋅Δ⋅ϵ3Δ)≤exp⁡(ϵ). \begin{aligned} \frac{\Pr \big[ \mathcal{A}(D) = s_i \Vert \vec X_{i - 1} = \vec x_{i - 1} \big]}{\Pr \big[ \mathcal{A}(D') = s_i \Vert \vec X_{i - 1} = \vec x_{i - 1} \big] } &= \frac{ \int \int p(z) \cdot p(x_i) \cdot \mathbb{I} \Big[ M(D, \vec x_{i - 1}) < t + z \le q_i(D) + x_i \Big] \, d x_i \, dz } { \int \int p(z') \cdot p(x_i') \cdot \mathbb{I} \Big[ M(D', \vec x_{i - 1}) < t + z' \le q_i(D') + x_i' \Big] \, d x_i' \, dz' } \\ &= \frac{ \int \int p(z) \cdot p(x_i) \cdot \mathbb{I} \Big[ M(D, \vec x_{i - 1}) < t + z \le q_i(D) + x_i \Big] \, d x_i \, dz } { \int \int p(z') \cdot p(x_i') \cdot \mathbb{I} \Big[ M(D, \vec x_{i - 1}) < t + z \le q_i(D) + x_i \Big] \, d x_i \, dz } \\ &\le \exp \Big( \Delta \cdot \frac{\epsilon}{3\Delta}\Big) \cdot \exp \Big( 2 \cdot \Delta \cdot \frac{\epsilon}{3\Delta} \Big) \\ &\le \exp(\epsilon). \end{aligned} Pr[A(D′)=si​∥Xi−1​=xi−1​]Pr[A(D)=si​∥Xi−1​=xi−1​]​​=∫∫p(z′)⋅p(xi′​)⋅I[M(D′,xi−1​)<t+z′≤qi​(D′)+xi′​]dxi′​dz′∫∫p(z)⋅p(xi​)⋅I[M(D,xi−1​)<t+z≤qi​(D)+xi​]dxi​dz​=∫∫p(z′)⋅p(xi′​)⋅I[M(D,xi−1​)<t+z≤qi​(D)+xi​]dxi​dz∫∫p(z)⋅p(xi​)⋅I[M(D,xi−1​)<t+z≤qi​(D)+xi​]dxi​dz​≤exp(Δ⋅3Δϵ​)⋅exp(2⋅Δ⋅3Δϵ​)≤exp(ϵ).​

Integrating over X⃗i−1=x⃗i−1\vec X_{i - 1} = \vec x_{i - 1}Xi−1​=xi−1​ for all possible x⃗i−1\vec x_{i - 1}xi−1​ proves that Pr⁡[A(D)=si]≤eϵ⋅Pr⁡[A(D′)=si]\Pr\big[ \mathcal{A}(D) = s_i \big] \le e^\epsilon \cdot \Pr\big[ \mathcal{A}(D') = s_i \big]Pr[A(D)=si​]≤eϵ⋅Pr[A(D′)=si​].

Mechanism Two

Definition. For each b∈R+b \in \mathbb{R}^+b∈R+, let Exp(b)\mathcal{Exp}(b)Exp(b) be the exponential distribution with parameter bbb.

The algorithm is described as follows.

Algorithm A\mathcal{A}A.

  1. t^←t+Z\hat t \leftarrow t + Zt^←t+Z where Z∼Exp(3Δ/ϵ)Z \sim \mathcal{Exp}(3 \Delta / \epsilon)Z∼Exp(3Δ/ϵ)
  2. for i∈N+i \in \mathbb{N}^+i∈N+ do
  3. \qquad q^i(D)←qi(D)+Xi\hat q_i(D) \leftarrow q_i(D) + X_iq^​i​(D)←qi​(D)+Xi​, where Xi∼Exp(3Δ/ϵ)X_i \sim \mathcal{Exp}( 3 \Delta / \epsilon)Xi​∼Exp(3Δ/ϵ)
  4. \qquad if q^i(D)≥t^\hat q_i(D) \ge \hat tq^​i​(D)≥t^ then
  5. \qquad\qquad output ⊥\bot⊥
  6. \qquad\qquad halt
  7. \qquad else
  8. \qquad\qquad output ⊤\top⊤

Privacy Guarantee

Let D′D'D′ be a neighboring dataset of DDD.

Theorem. For each i∈N+i \in \mathbb{N}^+i∈N+, let si≐⊤…⊤⏟i−1 occurrences⊥s_i \doteq \underbrace{\top \ldots \top}_{ i - 1 \text{ occurrences} } \botsi​≐i−1 occurrences⊤…⊤​​⊥.
Then

e−ϵ≤Pr⁡[A(D)=si]Pr⁡[A(D′)=si]≤eϵ. e^{-\epsilon} \le \frac{\Pr[ \mathcal{A}(D) = s_i ]}{\Pr[ \mathcal{A}(D') = s_i ]} \le e^{\epsilon}. e−ϵ≤Pr[A(D′)=si​]Pr[A(D)=si​]​≤eϵ.

THe analysis is very similar to the one for report noisy max.
Informally speaking, we are applying report noisy max twice, one for t^\hat tt^ being max among (t^,q^(D1),…,q^(Di−1))(\hat t, \hat q(D_1), \ldots, \hat q(D_{i - 1}))(t^,q^​(D1​),…,q^​(Di−1​)), one for q^(Di)\hat q(D_i)q^​(Di​) being max among (t^,q^(D1),…,q^(Di))(\hat t, \hat q(D_1), \ldots, \hat q(D_{i}))(t^,q^​(D1​),…,q^​(Di​)).

Proof.

Fix an i∈N+i \in \mathbb{N}^+i∈N+.

Denote X⃗i−1≐(X1,…,Xi−1)\vec X_{i - 1} \doteq (X_1, \ldots, X_{i - 1})Xi−1​≐(X1​,…,Xi−1​), and
The event A(D)=si\mathcal{A}(D) = s_iA(D)=si​ happens if and only if

Fix a sequence x⃗i−1=(x1,…,xi−1)∈Ri−1\vec x_{i - 1} = (x_1, \ldots, x_{i - 1} ) \in \mathbb{R}^{i - 1}xi−1​=(x1​,…,xi−1​)∈Ri−1.
Since the random variables Z,X⃗i−1,XiZ, \vec X_{i - 1}, X_iZ,Xi−1​,Xi​ are independent,

Pr⁡[A(D)=si∥X⃗i−1=x⃗i−1]=Pr⁡[M(D,x⃗i−1)<t^≤q^i(D)]=Pr⁡[M(D,x⃗i−1)<t+Z≤qi(D)+Xi]=∫M(D,x⃗i−1)−t∞(p(z)⋅∫t+z−qi(D)∞p(xi) dxi) dz=∫M(D,x⃗i−1)−t∞p(z)⋅exp⁡(−ϵ3Δ⋅max⁡{0,t+z−qi(D)}) dz \begin{aligned} \Pr \big[ \mathcal{A}(D) = s_i \Vert \vec X_{i - 1} = \vec x_{i - 1} \big] &= \Pr \big[ M(D, \vec x_{i - 1}) < \hat t \le \hat q_i(D) \big] \\ &= \Pr \big[ M(D, \vec x_{i - 1}) < t + Z \le q_i(D) + X_i \big] \\ &= \int_{M(D, \vec x_{i - 1}) - t}^\infty \left( p(z) \cdot \int_{t + z - q_i (D)}^\infty p(x_i) \, d x_i \right) \, dz \\ &= \int_{M(D, \vec x_{i - 1}) - t}^\infty p(z) \cdot \exp \left( -\frac{\epsilon}{3 \Delta} \cdot \max \big\{ 0, t + z - q_i (D) \big\} \right) \, dz \end{aligned} Pr[A(D)=si​∥Xi−1​=xi−1​]​=Pr[M(D,xi−1​)<t^≤q^​i​(D)]=Pr[M(D,xi−1​)<t+Z≤qi​(D)+Xi​]=∫M(D,xi−1​)−t∞​(p(z)⋅∫t+z−qi​(D)∞​p(xi​)dxi​)dz=∫M(D,xi−1​)−t∞​p(z)⋅exp(−3Δϵ​⋅max{0,t+z−qi​(D)})dz​

where p(z)p(z)p(z) and p(xi)p(x_i)p(xi​) are probability densities of ZZZ and XiX_iXi​, respectively.
For now, let

κ≐M(D,x⃗i−1)−M(D′,x⃗i−1)∈[−Δ,Δ]. \kappa \doteq M(D, \vec x_{i - 1}) - M(D', \vec x_{i - 1}) \in [- \Delta, \Delta] . κ≐M(D,xi−1​)−M(D′,xi−1​)∈[−Δ,Δ].

Following similar vein, the conditional probability density of Pr⁡[A(D′)=si]\Pr\big[ \mathcal{A}(D') = s_i \big]Pr[A(D′)=si​] is given by

Pr⁡[A(D′)=si∥X⃗i−1=x⃗i−1]=Pr⁡[M(D′,x⃗i−1)<t^≤q^i(D′)]=Pr⁡[M(D′,x⃗i−1)<t+Z≤qi(D′)+Xi]=∫M(D′,x⃗i−1)−t∞(p(z)⋅∫t+z−qi(D′)∞p(xi) dxi) dz=∫M(D′,x⃗i−1)−t∞p(z)⋅exp⁡(−ϵ3Δ⋅max⁡{0,t+z−qi(D′)}) dz=y≐z+κ∫M(D,x⃗i−1)−t∞p(y−κ)⋅exp⁡(−ϵ3Δ⋅max⁡{0,t+y−κ−qi(D′)}) dy \begin{aligned} \Pr \big[ \mathcal{A}(D') = s_i \Vert \vec X_{i - 1} = \vec x_{i - 1} \big] &= \Pr \big[ M(D', \vec x_{i - 1}) < \hat t \le \hat q_i(D') \big] \\ &= \Pr \big[ M(D', \vec x_{i - 1}) < t + Z \le q_i(D') + X_i \big] \\ &= \int_{M(D', \vec x_{i - 1}) - t}^\infty \left( p(z) \cdot \int_{t + z - q_i (D')}^\infty p(x_i) \, d x_i \right) \, dz \\ &= \int_{M(D', \vec x_{i - 1}) - t}^\infty p(z) \cdot \exp \left( -\frac{\epsilon}{3 \Delta} \cdot \max \big\{ 0, t + z - q_i (D') \big\} \right) \, dz \\ &\stackrel{y \doteq z + \kappa}{=} \int_{M(D, \vec x_{i - 1}) - t}^\infty p(y - \kappa) \cdot \exp \left( -\frac{\epsilon}{3 \Delta} \cdot \max \big\{ 0, t + y - \kappa - q_i (D') \big\} \right) \, dy \end{aligned} Pr[A(D′)=si​∥Xi−1​=xi−1​]​=Pr[M(D′,xi−1​)<t^≤q^​i​(D′)]=Pr[M(D′,xi−1​)<t+Z≤qi​(D′)+Xi​]=∫M(D′,xi−1​)−t∞​(p(z)⋅∫t+z−qi​(D′)∞​p(xi​)dxi​)dz=∫M(D′,xi−1​)−t∞​p(z)⋅exp(−3Δϵ​⋅max{0,t+z−qi​(D′)})dz=y≐z+κ∫M(D,xi−1​)−t∞​p(y−κ)⋅exp(−3Δϵ​⋅max{0,t+y−κ−qi​(D′)})dy​

Comparing the integrands we have

Pr⁡[A(D)=si∥X⃗i−1=x⃗i−1]Pr⁡[A(D′)=si∥X⃗i−1=x⃗i−1]≤exp⁡(ϵ). \begin{aligned} \frac{\Pr \big[ \mathcal{A}(D) = s_i \Vert \vec X_{i - 1} = \vec x_{i - 1} \big]}{\Pr \big[ \mathcal{A}(D') = s_i \Vert \vec X_{i - 1} = \vec x_{i - 1} \big] } &\le \exp(\epsilon). \end{aligned} Pr[A(D′)=si​∥Xi−1​=xi−1​]Pr[A(D)=si​∥Xi−1​=xi−1​]​​≤exp(ϵ).​

Integrating over X⃗i−1=x⃗i−1\vec X_{i - 1} = \vec x_{i - 1}Xi−1​=xi−1​ for all possible x⃗i−1\vec x_{i - 1}xi−1​ proves that Pr⁡[A(D)=si]≤eϵ⋅Pr⁡[A(D′)=si]\Pr\big[ \mathcal{A}(D) = s_i \big] \le e^\epsilon \cdot \Pr\big[ \mathcal{A}(D') = s_i \big]Pr[A(D)=si​]≤eϵ⋅Pr[A(D′)=si​].

□\square□

Utility Guarantee

Suppose that the algorithm outputs ⊤\top⊤ at the iii-th query, we measure the empirical error by max⁡{0,qi(D)−t}\max \{0, q_i(D) - t \}max{0,qi​(D)−t}, i.e., if qi(D)q_i(D)qi​(D) does not exceed ttt, then we regards the empirical error as 000.
Similarly, for an output ⊥\bot⊥, the empirical error is measured by max⁡{0,t−qi(D)}\max \{0, t - q_i(D) \}max{0,t−qi​(D)}.

Theorem. Fix a sequence of kkk queries q1,…,qkq_1, \ldots, q_kq1​,…,qk​ to be performed by the algorithm. With probability at most β\betaβ, the
maximum empirical error exceeds

6⋅Δϵln⁡k+1β. \frac{6 \cdot \Delta}{\epsilon}\ln \frac{k + 1}{\beta}. ϵ6⋅Δ​lnβk+1​.

Proof.

Pr⁡[∣Z∣≥2⋅Δϵln⁡k+1β]≤exp⁡(2⋅ln⁡k+1β)=βk+1. \Pr \left[ |Z| \ge \frac{2 \cdot \Delta}{\epsilon}\ln \frac{k + 1}{\beta} \right] \le \exp \left( 2 \cdot \ln \frac{k + 1}{\beta} \right) = \frac{\beta}{k + 1}. Pr[∣Z∣≥ϵ2⋅Δ​lnβk+1​]≤exp(2⋅lnβk+1​)=k+1β​.

Similarly, for each i∈[k]i \in [k]i∈[k],

Pr⁡[∣Xi∣≥2⋅Δϵln⁡k+1β]≤exp⁡(2⋅ln⁡k+1β)=βk+1. \Pr \left[ |X_i| \ge \frac{2 \cdot \Delta}{\epsilon}\ln \frac{k + 1}{\beta} \right] \le \exp \left( 2 \cdot \ln \frac{k + 1}{\beta} \right) = \frac{\beta}{k + 1}. Pr[∣Xi​∣≥ϵ2⋅Δ​lnβk+1​]≤exp(2⋅lnβk+1​)=k+1β​.

By union bound, with probability at most β\betaβ, it holds that

∣Z∣+max⁡i∈[k]∣Xi∣≥6⋅Δϵln⁡k+1β. |Z| + \max_{i \in [k]} |X_i| \ge \frac{6 \cdot \Delta}{\epsilon}\ln \frac{k + 1}{\beta}. ∣Z∣+i∈[k]max​∣Xi​∣≥ϵ6⋅Δ​lnβk+1​.

□\square□
